geoOrigin: North East Lincolnshire, England, United Kingdom
description: The return of their football has certainly shown the way forward for the English game, with the Premier League and latterly the Championship since going public with their plans to restart later this month. When you have players like Troy Deeney, who has a young child with respiratory problems, understandably refusing to play, how can we guarantee the...
text:
IT seems fitting that the first major European football league to return was
the German Bundesliga.

I don't wish to dine out on national stereotypes - but sometimes, there's no
smoke without fire. So, when their response to the Coronavirus and political
leadership has been suitably well organised and efficient, certainly in
comparison to our own; you have to wonder if they'll start beating us in
penalty shoot-outs again soon!

The return of their football has certainly shown the way forward for the
English game, with the Premier League and latterly the Championship since
going public with their plans to restart later this month.

This is to be welcomed, but only if they can ensure that everyone involved is
safe and it doesn't detract from wider coronavirus-tackling efforts across
society. And at the minute, that's an awfully big if.

When you have players like Troy Deeney, who has a young child with respiratory
problems, understandably refusing to play, how can we guarantee the
competition's integrity? Let's hope that clubs like Watford are not unduly
penalised for their key players having caring responsibilities.

Some clubs have tried to resist football's resumption, seemingly largely
driven by self-interest, but it has been good to see those wrecking efforts
resisted.

These teething problems notwithstanding, even though football has almost been
officially cancelled in League Two (with League One expected to be resolved
next in some form or another); the Championship's return does bode well for
lower league clubs.

Hopefully it will help solve once and for all the ongoing issue of promotion
and relegation throughout the pyramid. When you look at the ongoing purgatory
the likes of Barrow and Crewe have faced this last two months, mid-table
mediocrity has never felt so good.

What the likes of Grimsby Town will be hoping is that Championship sides
returning to action will provide robust examples of how live matches and
contact training sessions can be run safely.

What are the safety precautions like? How are we ensuring there can be no
spike in cases? How has football's integrity been affected by the three month-
plus sabbatical? These questions can only be answered over time, but are
particularly crucial in League Two and below - where there is no doubt that
clubs can't afford to stage games behind closed doors. Let's just hope that
this can be run well, with effective lessons learned from the inevitable bumps
in the road and mistakes. This is the EFL after all.

A number of clubs at our level have expressed hopes that live football could
be back by September, which given this is when the Championship provisionally
hopes that it will be able to start next season by; seems reasonably sensible
- if perhaps a touch ambitious given the country's ongoing issues, and by
international comparisons, our relatively large number of ongoing cases.

Clubs should be strongly considering following the lead of a policy set by
Polish football, which has set a capacity limit of 25 per cent for returning
football.

It's not that much of a stretch when you think that attendances for League Two
matches often do not come anywhere near to a ground's capacity.

If that's the price of not only returning to live football, but also doing so
in a safe and sustainable manner; then sign me up.

I know I'm not the only one who feels like this, and supporters consistently
express the same hopes. Because after nearly three months of lockdown and the
total suspension of live football; standing on a sparsely populated terrace
watching mediocre action has never sounded like such heaven.

CREDIT: By MAX BELL
[sport@grimsbytelegraph.co.uk](mailto:sport@grimsbytelegraph.co.uk)
@Max_Bell_11

CAPTION: Grimsby Town and Scunthorpe United will be able to look to the
Championship for examples of how live matches and contact training sessions
can be run safely.

title: Championship restart bodes well for League Two's hopes: columnist max bell says league two can learn from championship - and prepare for a september start
html:
IT seems fitting that the first major European football league to return was the German Bundesliga.

I don't wish to dine out on national stereotypes - but sometimes, there's no smoke without fire. So, when their response to the Coronavirus and political leadership has been suitably well organised and efficient, certainly in comparison to our own; you have to wonder if they'll start beating us in penalty shoot-outs again soon!

The return of their football has certainly shown the way forward for the English game, with the Premier League and latterly the Championship since going public with their plans to restart later this month.

This is to be welcomed, but only if they can ensure that everyone involved is safe and it doesn't detract from wider coronavirus-tackling efforts across society. And at the minute, that's an awfully big if.

When you have players like Troy Deeney, who has a young child with respiratory problems, understandably refusing to play, how can we guarantee the competition's integrity? Let's hope that clubs like Watford are not unduly penalised for their key players having caring responsibilities.

Some clubs have tried to resist football's resumption, seemingly largely driven by self-interest, but it has been good to see those wrecking efforts resisted.

These teething problems notwithstanding, even though football has almost been officially cancelled in League Two (with League One expected to be resolved next in some form or another); the Championship's return does bode well for lower league clubs.

Hopefully it will help solve once and for all the ongoing issue of promotion and relegation throughout the pyramid. When you look at the ongoing purgatory the likes of Barrow and Crewe have faced this last two months, mid-table mediocrity has never felt so good.

What the likes of Grimsby Town will be hoping is that Championship sides returning to action will provide robust examples of how live matches and contact training sessions can be run safely.

What are the safety precautions like? How are we ensuring there can be no spike in cases? How has football's integrity been affected by the three month-plus sabbatical? These questions can only be answered over time, but are particularly crucial in League Two and below - where there is no doubt that clubs can't afford to stage games behind closed doors. Let's just hope that this can be run well, with effective lessons learned from the inevitable bumps in the road and mistakes. This is the EFL after all.

A number of clubs at our level have expressed hopes that live football could be back by September, which given this is when the Championship provisionally hopes that it will be able to start next season by; seems reasonably sensible - if perhaps a touch ambitious given the country's ongoing issues, and by international comparisons, our relatively large number of ongoing cases.

Clubs should be strongly considering following the lead of a policy set by Polish football, which has set a capacity limit of 25 per cent for returning football.

It's not that much of a stretch when you think that attendances for League Two matches often do not come anywhere near to a ground's capacity.

If that's the price of not only returning to live football, but also doing so in a safe and sustainable manner; then sign me up.

I know I'm not the only one who feels like this, and supporters consistently express the same hopes. Because after nearly three months of lockdown and the total suspension of live football; standing on a sparsely populated terrace watching mediocre action has never sounded like such heaven.

CREDIT: By MAX BELL sport@grimsbytelegraph.co.uk @Max_Bell_11

CAPTION: Grimsby Town and Scunthorpe United will be able to look to the Championship for examples of how live matches and contact training sessions can be run safely.
